awd_titl_txt: Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology: Development, Evolution, and Genetic Mechanisms of Regionalization within the Axial Column: Aves (Birds) as a Model System
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2022, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. This research addresses fundamental questions in biology; namely, how new anatomical traits evolve and how living things diversify. Although developmental differences in the structure and regionalization of the axial column (the spine, shoulders and hips) determine much of diversity in vertebrates, the function, structure, evolution and development of these differences remains largely unknown. This comparative study of how regions of fused vertebrae develop and evolve in birds is thus critical to better understand the genetics behind these processes, how the skeleton develops, and how vertebrates evolve. New collections will be produced for the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History (NMNH), which will support future research in vertebrate evolution, and will provide the fellow with training necessary to pursue cutting-edge interdisciplinary research across paleontology and biology. This research will provide mentorship and training to undergraduate interns. The fellow will use this research as a springboard to contribute to NMNH public and educational programs as well as complete 36 classroom visits to minoritized middle and high schools.

The fellow will use genetic, developmental, morphological, and evolutionary approaches to study the evolution of the axial skeleton of birds in a phylogenetic and functional context, describe and track the development of vertebral column fusion across five bird species, and study gene expression associated with these fusions across these species. Birds provide an excellent study system in which to study trait evolution in the vertebral column, as their spine presents a natural experimental system with three regions of bone fusion, each with a separate evolutionary history. Few studies regarding the axial column have focused on birds, and those that have largely examine only one study species. The fellow will conduct fieldwork and work with breeders to collect avian embryos and chicks and will use phylogenetic analysis and fossil calibration, specimen imaging and dissection, creation of ontogenetic series, and transcriptome extraction and analysis to investigate evolutionary and ecological, developmental, and gene expression rules regarding the axial column. The fellow will receive training in these methods, and broader impacts will focus on broadening participation of the public, undergraduates and minoritized students in STEM.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History

por.por_cntn:
Some of the most fundamental questions in biology are how organisms diversify and how biodiversity is maintained. Differences in vertebral column elongation, modularity and structure during development are some of the most critical parameters generating anatomical diversity in vertebrates. Despite this, few studies have examined these factors in a comparative context, and the homology, function, and evolutionary and developmental constraints governing these changes remain largely unknown. Due to this we chose to investigate “Rules of Life” related to these questions using a combination of genetic, developmental, morphological, and evolutionary approaches. Using Aves (birds) as a model system, we studied the evolution of the avian vertebral column in a phylogenetic context, tested the function of fused vertebrae in the thoracic region, described and tracked the development of three areas of fusion in the avian vertebral column across five species, and are in the process of identifying and comparing the genetic mechanisms behind these fusions across these species.

We conducted fieldwork and worked with breeders to collect avian embryos and chicks and used phylogenetic analysis and fossil calibration, specimen imaging and dissection, creation of ontogenetic (embryo and chick development) series, and transcriptome (RNA) extraction and analysis to address the proposed questions. All data for the research has been collected and most analyses have been completed with the exception of transcriptome sequencing, which we are in the process of completing. Forthcoming publications, presentations and outreach will detail our results. This project is also the first to involve collection and preservation of known-age late-stage embryos and chicks in an ontogenetic series for multiple species, which are now accessioned into the Ornithology Collections of the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History (NMNH) and the Academy of Natural Sciences at Drexel University, where they are available to others for study. In total we collected 936 transcriptome samples from 117 individuals across 3 non-model avian species that are currently stored in the Biorepository of NMNH, collected 173 specimens across five non-model bird species to create the ontogenetic series, created 89 x-ray computed tomography scans comprising 15 species, created a new phylogenetic matrix detailing avian vertebral evolution, produced wing measurements for hundreds of individuals across five species, and created a new protocol for transcriptome sampling in the field as well as many videos and photographs documenting the produced specimens and new method.

This research integrated developmental biology, phylogenetics, comparative anatomy, and paleontology to aid in answering fundamental questions in vertebrate evolution. Forthcoming results are critical for better understanding how vertebrates diversify; the genetic mechanisms behind these processes; the homology of structure, development and ossification across birds; and evolutionary modules within vertebrates and their ability to evolve independently in response to selective pressures. Results may have impacts for human medicine as well, as gene expression study may identify important new candidate genes for axial fusion. Additionally, our methods and research products will be useful for geneticists and developmental biologists in better establishing protocols for studying development and gene expression in non-model species. All research products will be open-access and made available in online repositories. Publications will be made publicly accessible when possible. All results of the study will be disseminated broadly via presentations at local, national, and international conferences, scholarly journals, and public lectures. Completion of fieldwork and specimen preparation included recruiting an undergraduate intern from the NMNH Natural History Research Experiences 10-week summer internship program, an NSF REU program, during which we provided them with research-based Museum and field training and mentorship. Research was also detailed during outreach events for the public at Q?rius within NMNH.

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2024
Modified by: Grace Musser
